Revealed: The truth behind Lad Culture at York

14/09/2013

Interviewing nine of York's sport team members, Tess Farley uncovers the reality behind the beer, the banging and the banter.

Image by

By undefined undefined

The NUS recently called for a summit on Lad Culture, following findings from an independent research project, 'That's What She Said', conducted by the University of Sussex. The results were more than concerning, reporting sexual abuse on dance floors, women being subjected to 'rape jokes', and student social life being dominated by binge-drinking and worryingly prevalent misogynistic and homophobic attitudes. But it's all "banter", right? So, how does the NUS report measure up to lad culture at York, and how do our students feel about it? The consensus amongst the range of male and female students I interviewed was that lad culture does dominate social affairs at York, although it seems to be relatively tame in comparison to some bigger city universities. Views reinforce that, whilst present in halls, societies and even course groups, lad culture is most prevalent in sports teams. Behaviour on tour ('what goes on tour stays on tour'), initiations and socials demonstrate the most extreme examples. Secrecy and a reluctance to share what really goes on during initiations and socials renders it difficult to gage just how extreme our sports teams' behaviour really is. That said, it's no secret that the rugby team, who have a 'no girl's before Ziggies' rule and enforce punishments and drinking penalties (even for missing socials due to academic pressures or deadlines), is popularly labeled as the worst. So what do sports players think about lad culture? I asked a variety of sports team members, from clubs including rugby, boxing, netball, cheerleading, lacrosse and American football. Unsurprisingly, all wanted to stay anonymous so have been given false names. Here's what they had to say:

Do sports teams encourage lad culture? And how?

John: The sports teams tend to encourage a lad culture, some much more than others...the rugby team set off a flare in Ziggies some while back. Emily: The reason has to be that on a social an inherently competitive forum comes into contact with drinking and thus the drinking itself becomes a competition too. George: ...Pulling girls just for the sake of it, drinking copious amounts in inventive ways. Emily: A few boys thought it would be a good idea to play an augmented version of centurion which they dubbed spartan: 300 shots for 300 minutes. Madness. Lily: "Fuck Me I'm a Fresher" posters/mentality help to fuel it. Zoe: Only care is pulling girls. There is no camaraderie between the boys. Fliss: One guy pooed in a girl's makeup bag after spending the night at hers - for a "laugh". Lily: I've had a fancy dress costume ripped off me on a sports social, by a "Rugby Lad", for no reason - I didn't even know the guy. It was such a violent, random action, and I was left in tears. George: People actively go out to try and do outrageous things so they can tell other people about it and have themselves accepted as a participating member of the culture.' Without exception, all of the participants admitted that lad culture existed, that it could get out of hand, and that they didn't agree or weren't comfortable with some of the behaviour they'd witnessed or participated in.

So why does it happen?

Emily: I think that it's to do with peer pressure - pressure to project an image in order to be accepted by the group even if that image doesn't correspond with your natural personality. Hatti: The pressures are equal for both boys and girls, speaking from personal experience. George: Freshers see a certain few confident types being "Lads" and getting positive attention and end up craving the same attention. Without anyone telling them to, they feel pressure to "step up their game"...You do things for the sake of it, get more drunk than you've ever been before and become more susceptible to outside pressure. John: People are encouraged to down loads of drinks or say inappropriate things to girls, when you can see they really don't want to... There are some who just can't say no largely because of the pressure. George: You're surrounded by people saying outrageous things and putting outrageous ideas in your head. Mix this with copious amounts of alcohol and the results can be... interesting...You get grey areas whereby people are told to do things, given the option to not, but then owe a forfeit for not participating. People who don't want to participate end up leaving the clubs.

What are the consequences?

George: The culture creates unity and togetherness. You're part of a supportive group that has each other's backs, and that shouldn't be undervalued. Peter: I think theres a line between male camaraderie and then going too far to try and impress people.. I feel a little bit of the behaviour helps team spirit and bonding but if it goes too far then it's just children showing off. John: [it] can be great for, like, team bonding and making mates but can also go too far. Groups of lads are made to feel almost like celebrities, simply because of the sport they play. Lad culture is largely centred around hooking up with as many girls as possible... Some lads think that girls will sleep with them simply because of who they are or what sport they play (sometimes this is sadly the case). It makes them think inappropriate behaviour is acceptable and it's difficult to change that perception. It makes people who don't like that kind of behaviour either feel intimidated or pretend to be something they're not... I think it kind of stops guys from being who they really are, along with potentially causing further issues down the line. But it also doesn't help in developing healthy relationships. Peter: I think the few taint the opinions of the whole group. George: It's disrespectful to women 'cause it treats them like a sport almost. John: It also isn't helped by some girls. Tom: Once you're in, you're massively stereotyped. Emily: Lad culture definitely affects my own behaviour. Tom: I have a lot of friends in the rugby club. Away from the rugby club they are kind, smart guys. But as soon as they are out on a rugby social I wouldn't go anywhere near them. They act completely out of character and are obscenely rude. They are "punished" for talking to girls before ziggies...I find the whole thing bewildering and pathetic. Fliss: There have been times when I have laughed off laddish comments or jokes that have been made in a sexist light towards women, when perhaps I shouldn't have. Hatti: I have been involved in and bothered by lad and ladette culture. George: But having said all that, will I be involved in what's come to be known as lad culture in the future? Inevitably yes. As well as the worrying disclosures above documenting dangerous and at times abusive behaviour, it seems a shame that earning your colours now seems to be more about how many shots you can drink without chundering on your brogues or how many people you've pulled, rather than sporting achievement. It seems a shame that some people I interviewed have left sports clubs or been discouraged from joining them because they don't want to partake in lad culture or earn the stereotype. The thing I find most thought provoking is that, without exception, every interviewee felt that it was paramount they remain anonymous, and yet they all felt similarly. Perhaps if we all realised that most people feel the same way, we might be less inclined to censor how we really feel. We might feel more able to pioneer a new, improved lad culture: sifting through the dirt to find the gold. After all, we're York students. We're intelligent enough to think for ourselves, and to act on those thoughts, aren't we?
